original.definition: tour the country in order to solicit votes for an election

sememes.reasoning: The definition 'solicit votes for an election' directly corresponds to the activity of campaigning, as indicated by the hypernym 'campaign.v.01'.

participants.reasoning: The 'Somebody' in the verb frame is the individual who performs the action of campaigning.
The explicit purpose of the action is to 'solicit votes', making 'votes' the goal.

sememes.reasoning: The 'whistlestop' aspect and the phrase 'tour the country' in the definition specify the particular manner in which the campaigning action is conducted, involving extensive travel.

Evidentiality.reasoning: A whistlestop tour is a publicly observable political event.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is declarative, describing an action performed.

Modality.reasoning: The 'Somebody' in the frame implies an agent acting with strong will and intention to achieve political goals.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of campaigning itself is neutral; its outcomes or associated opinions may be positive or negative.

Volitionality.reasoning: The frame 'Somebody ----s' clearly indicates a volitional agent performing an intentional political action.

Confidence.reasoning: The verb describes a definite occurrence or an intentional activity being undertaken.

Iterativity.reasoning: A 'whistlestop tour' inherently involves a series of stops, speeches, and interactions, signifying a highly repetitive and continuous activity rather than a single event.

participants.reasoning: value_type 'votes.n.01' is not a valid synset in NLTK.

candidates.description: a choice that is made by counting the number of people in favor of each alternative (gloss match)
an election in which each person has as many votes as there are positions to be filled and they can all be cast for one candidate or can be distributed in any manner (gloss match)
a vote in which each person's choice is secret but the totaled votes are public (gloss match)
a ballot cast by a voter who votes for candidates from more than one party (gloss match)
a ballot cast by a voter who votes for all the candidates of one party (gloss match)
the counting of votes (as in an election) (gloss match)
an additional (usually a second) count; especially of the votes in a close election (gloss match)
act of exchanging favors for mutual gain; especially trading of influence or votes among legislators to gain passage of certain projects (gloss match)
a temporary booth in a polling place which people enter to cast their votes (gloss match)
a mechanical device for recording and counting votes mechanically (gloss match)
a published written account of the speeches and debates and votes of the United States Congress (gloss match)
ultimate success achieved after a near failure (inspired by the saying `he laughs best who laughs last') (gloss match)
a place where voters go to cast their votes in an election (gloss match)
a member of a constituency; a citizen who is represented in a government by officials for whom he or she votes (gloss match)
a person who takes or counts votes (gloss match)
a voter who is registered as a member of one political party but who votes in the primary of another party (gloss match)
a voter who votes illegally at different polling places in the same election (gloss match)
someone who devotes himself completely (gloss match)
a leader in a political party who controls votes and dictates appointments (gloss match)
a person who is important by virtue of the people or votes they control (gloss match)
a scientist who devotes himself to doing research (gloss match)
someone who examines votes at an election (gloss match)
a petitioner who solicits contributions or trade or votes (gloss match)
a candidate with no chance of winning but who may draw enough votes to prevent one of the leading candidates from winning (gloss match)
an official appointed to count the votes (especially in legislative assembly) (gloss match)
(politics) the consequence of one popular candidate in an election drawing votes for other members of the same political party (gloss match)
compensation received by virtue of holding an office or having employment (usually in the form of wages or fees) (gloss match)
a fund for buying votes or bribing public officials (gloss match)
(elections) more than half of the votes (gloss match)
(in an election with more than 2 options) the number of votes for the candidate or party receiving the greatest number (but less that half of the votes) (gloss match)

participants.corrected_reasoning: vote.n.01 is the singular form and a perfect semantic match for the invalid plural votes.n.01 from the candidates list.
